front.title: ACVP Message Authentication Algorithm JSON Specification

abstract.t: This document defines the JSON schema for using HMAC and CMAC algorithms with the ACVP specification.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing HMAC and CMAC crypto algorithms using ACVP.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted in RFC 2119.

section.title: Capabilities Registration
section.t: ACVP requires crypto modules to register their capabilities. This allows the crypto module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of HMAC and CMAC algorithms to the ACVP server.

The algorithm capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algorithms' value of the ACVP registration message. The 'algorithms' value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The 'algorithms' value is part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: Required Prerequisite Algorithms for MAC Validations
section.t: Each MAC implementation relies on other cryptographic primitives. For example, CMAC uses an underlying SHA algorithm. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

texttable.title: Required MAC Prerequisite Algorithms JSON Values
texttable.c: object with algorithm and valValue properties

section.title: MAC Algorithm Capabilities Registration
section.t: Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values.

texttable.title: MAC Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: The MAC algorithm and mode to be validated.
prerequistie algorithm validations, See for examples
The MAC direction(s) to test. Only applies to CMAC.
The keyLen Domain supported by the IUT in bits. (HMAC only)
The array of keyLens supported by the IUT in bits. (CMAC-AES only)

The Keying Option used in TDES.
Keying option 1 (1) is 3 distinct keys (K1, K2, K3). Keying Option 2 (2) is 2 distinct only suitable for decrypt (K1, K2, K1). Keying option 3 (No longer valid for testing, save TDES KATs) is a single key, now deprecated (K1, K1, K1).
The CMAC message lengths supported in bits. Min/max/increment and values must be mod 8.
The supported mac sizes. (range dependent on algorithm, see ).

section.t: Note: Some optional values are required depending on the algorithm. Failure to provide these values will result in the ACVP server returning an error to the ACVP client during registration.
keyLen for HMAC contains a Domain of values, the server may choose values defined by these rules:

list.t: 2 values below the Hash's block length. See
2 values above the Hash's block length.

section.t: macLen for CMAC contains a Domain of values, the server may choose values defined by these rules:
msgLen for CMAC contains a Domain of values, the server may choose values defined by these rules:

list.t: Two message lengths divisible by block size
Two message lengths NOT divisible by block size

section.title: Supported MAC Algorithms
section.t: The following algorithms may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

texttable.title: Algorithms w/ block size and max MAC length.

section.title: Test Vectors
section.t: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual crypto algorithm, such as HMAC-SHA-1, HMAC-SHA2-224, CMAC-AES, etc. This section describes the JSON schema for a test vector set used with HMAC and CMAC crypto algorithms.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

texttable.title: Vector Set JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
The algorithm and mode used for the test vectors. See for possible values.
Array of test group JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Groups JSON Schema
section.t: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the secure HMAC and CMAC JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.

texttable.title: Test Group JSON Object
texttable.c: The direction of the tests - gen or ver - only applies to CMAC
Length of key in bits to use
Length of MAC in bits to generate/verify
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Case JSON Schema
section.t: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each secure MAC test vector.

texttable.title: Test Case JSON Object
texttable.c: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set.
Encryption keys to use for TDES

section.title: Test Vector Responses
section.t: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it must send the response vectors back to the ACVP server. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

texttable.title: Vector Set Response JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of JSON objects that represent each test vector result and is made up of one of the following values

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Security considerations are addressed by the ACVP specification.
